title: Are carbon steel knives safe for food contact? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are carbon steel knives safe for food contact? Absolutely and it’s been used safely for centuries! There’s been a huge push for stainless knives in modern times based solely upon the marketing sales pitches rather than actual scientific and engineering facts. For starters, very few stainless alloys can be heat-treated and hardened to the level of carbon steel. This is critically important when it comes to cutting tools because the tool’s value is determined by balance of three factors:1. Ability to hold an edge.2. Strength.3. Wear resistance. When it comes to knives in particular, two additional attributes are added:4. Ease of sharpening.5. Corrosion resistance. Here’s where the science and engineering facts come into play … alloys with high corrosion resistance generally have lower wear resistance, less strength and less edge-holding ability while being difficult to sharpen. Alloys with extreme edge holding abilities are typically wear resistant, but difficult to sharpen and have lower strength and corrosion resistance. Thus, the best knife alloys focus on edge holding, strength and wear resistance because ease of sharpening and corrosion resistance are secondary concerns. 1095 and 5160 are two of the most common carbon steels used for knives because they have the correct balance of strength and edge-holding ability, but lack a little in wear resistance over tools steels like O1 and D2; however, the latter two also lack the strength afforded by 1095 and 5160. Therefore, the ultimate blade is one that is known as being “bimetal” or “two metals”. This is where the cutting edge is a narrow strip made from O1 or D2 and is welded to a spine made from 1095 or 5160. This arrangement still leaves some things to be desired since overstressing the blade can cause the edge to fracture while the spine remains resilient. Thus, until one bites the bullet and drops sufficient coin on a true forge-welded laminated blade (a/k/a pattern welded), the best choice of blade is going to remain carbon steel alloy of 1095 or 5160. If your kitchen blades are rusting, you have not properly cared for them. Personally, I rust-blue the blades I make, but nonetheless, the sharpened edge and other wear spots remain bare steel which never rusts because they’re properly cared for. Rust blue is the conversion of the unstable iron oxide Fe2O3 into the stable iron oxide Fe2O4 and when done properly it looks like this steel (sorry, don’t have a picture of a blade handy but the finish is the same as appears here on the action and barrels):  Fe2O4 is stable and highly resistance to corrosion with moderate care. The nature of the finish also makes it essentially non-stick so carbon steel knife blades finished with true rust blue will not have things like potato slices glued to them by the starch and raw animal tallow does not leave a heavy residue build-up while cutting as happens with all other alloys. Yes, I do admit to having some stainless steel blades and even the two the are extremely expensive do not perform as good as my old carbon steel blades and they certainly don’t even come close to comparing to a decent forge-welded laminated steel blade. Yes. Carbon knives will, however, start to corrode and oxidize in the presence of moisture and acid. To help stop knife material from getting onto the food, you need to build a stable patina on the blade. This acts as a barrier that helps to prevent self-perpetuating orange rust from forming and damaging the blade as well as to prevent the same from rubbing off onto the food. Care must still be taken with acidic foods because, especially if the acid is strong and the patina is not well-established, the acid can remove the patina and transfer it to the food. This is not harmful and typically doesn’t even happen but can affect flavor and appearance when it does. Rust in and of itself it actually not hazardous, either. Tetanus doesn’t just appear magically in rust. That’s not how bacteria works. It comes from the outdoor environment. Other bacteria cannot survive for a long time on naked dry steel. A small amount of rust on an indoor knife that has had maybe a few days at most to even begin rusting will not make you sick. As long as the person using the knife washes and dries it after the end of every shift, there is no reason to worry about knives in particular. I’d be more wary of plastic cutting boards. Also remember the vast majority of kitchen knives used today throughout the world are still non-stainless carbon. And virtually all of them from about a century ago and all the way throughout the existence of metal knives were reactive.

Absolutely. High carbon blades can be made into top grade chef knives. The only real consideration with a high carbon steel is that it WILL rust if left wet. Wiping your blade frequently to keep the blade clean and free of moisture will help with this. Also, you can have a high carbon blade treated in order to create a patina, which creates a layer of hard oxides on the surface of the knife. It may look dirty, but the black oxidation actually seals the surface of the steel and keeps it safer from moisture. In fact, here’s an article written for the publication Serious Eats by a culinary director about why chefs SHOULD use carbon knives if they’re serious chefs. You can clearly see the discoloration on his blade, however this is not a problem and is desirable for a carbon blade. Why Serious Cooks Use Carbon Steel Knives

Yes carbon steel knives are safe for food contact but if used on strongly acid or salty food they can leave some staining. The problem with carbon steel is it rusts if not dried carefully after using. If there is much humidity carbon steel knives might even need to have a light coating of cooking oil to prevent them from rusting. The problem of rust leaving ugly looking stains on food is why almost all my kitchen knives are stainless. Not because of any fear about the regular steel leaving rust stains being unhealthy, but just because it does not look nice.

Carbon steels can be made into a fine kitchen knife. They are preferred over stainless steel by the top chef in Japan. I have a carbon steel knife that I know was owned and used by my grandpa in 1915. perhaps longer. It is still a fine knife. Carbon steel knives require more careful care than stainless steel ones. They need to be washed and wiped dry frequently and before every storage. The patina that develops on a well-cared-for carbon steel knife is somewhat rust-resistant, safe for food contact.

Are carbon steel knives safe for food contact? It’d be more correct to ask, “Is food safe for carbon steel contact?” ;) Carbon steel is chemically almost identical to cast iron, it just has a bit less carbon in it. So the steel won’t bother food. Carbon steel’s problem is a lack of corrosion resistance. A well-kept carbon steel chef’s knife won’t have issues, but other carbon steels can corrode easily thanks to all the salts, acids, and other chemicals found in food.

Yes, but they may react with some foods discoloring either the knife, the food, or both. None is harmful, usually won’t affect the taste of the food, although you might not like the way it looks. In some cases, some of the iron in the knife may dissolve into the food, but in exceedingly small amounts, and unless you have a rare disease affecting your iron levels, harmless to most people.

Quite safe. But, the whole origin of stainless steel was making an alloy that was cheaper than silver alloys that can cut fruit or salad without it instantly turning brown. “Stainless” steel is about not discoloring food and not the same a “doesn’t rust”. The only health problem you might possibly have is if you have a very rare sensitivity to iron. Clean your knives immediately after use and keep them oiled. Never put a good knife in the dishwasher.

Yes. Professional chefs use them. That's right: carbon steel stays sharper longer than stainless. Second, and this is really important, carbon steel, despite being harder than stainless steel, is way easier to sharpen than stainless.* This is critical because knives that are used frequently simply don't stay very sharp for long.

They used to be the standard some years ago. Carbon steel is softer than stainless so easier to sharpen but got dull more quickly so they needed more maintenance. They discoloured easily, particularly with acid foods. Any knife should be cleaned after each use but it really shows with carbon steel when they're not.

Basic metallurgy Iron + carbon equals steel Carbon makes iron steel. So all steel is carbon steel. … Answer Yes carbon steel is safe for contact with food. The carbon is sequestered inside the crystal structure of the iron. The iron does not dissolve in the food.
